title: Aisuru Botnet Shifts from DDoS to Residential Proxies
summary: The Aisuru botnet, initially known for executing Distributed Denial-of-Service (DDoS) attacks, has transitioned its operations towards establishing a network of residential proxies. This shift allows the botnet's operators to leverage compromised devices, particularly routers and IoT gadgets, to mask their activities and provide proxy services that disguise malicious traffic as legitimate residential data. title: Chicago Sun Times: ICE has powerful facial recognition app Illinois cops are barred from using — with little apparent oversight
summary: Illinois law enforcement agencies are prohibited from using a powerful facial recognition app provided by the U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) due to state regulations. The app allows users to upload photos and compare them against a database of millions of images, potentially identifying individuals for immigration enforcement. title: The 5 generative AI security threats you need to know about detailed in new e-book
summary: A recent e-book has outlined five critical security threats posed by generative AI technologies. These include the misuse of AI for generating phishing attacks and deepfake materials that make deceptive content more convincing and widespread. Additionally, there's concern over AI models being manipulated to leak sensitive information or to amplify misinformation. The e-book also highlights the risks associated with AI systems being compromised through adversarial attacks, which could alter their outputs in harmful ways. title: Suspected Nation-State Threat Actor Uses New Airstalk Malware in a Supply Chain Attack
summary: The article discusses a sophisticated cyberattack attributed to a suspected nation-state threat actor, which employed a newly identified malware called "Airstalk" in a supply chain attack. title: Microsoft Detects "SesameOp" Backdoor Using OpenAI's API as a Stealth Command Channel
summary: Microsoft has identified a new cybersecurity threat called "SesameOp," which utilizes OpenAI's API as a stealthy command and control channel for a backdoor. This sophisticated method exploits the API's capabilities to mask malicious communication within legitimate data exchanges, making it challenging to detect. title: Microsoft: SesameOp malware abuses OpenAI Assistants API in attacks
summary: The article discusses a new malware named SesameOp, which exploits vulnerabilities in OpenAI's Assistants API to conduct cyberattacks. Developed by Microsoft, the report highlights how SesameOp uses this access to manipulate AI responses and execute malicious activities, potentially affecting users who interact with compromised systems. The malware's sophistication lies in its ability to seamlessly blend with normal functionalities of AI tools, making detection challenging.
